titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Moses Kunitz papers, Rockefeller University Faculty FA171

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2015-11-22 09:18:40 -0500.

change.date: finding aid revision date not supplied
change.item: Paper finding aid converted to EAD/XML by AureXus in 2010. Imported into the Archvistsâ€™ Toolkit by Becky Robbins.

did.unittitle: Moses Kunitz papers, Rockefeller University Faculty

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Moses Kunitz, 1887-1978 researcher in general pathology and biochemistry worked on the physical and chemical properties of proteins and enzymes at the Rockefeller University (earlier RIMR) from 1913 until his retirement in 1970. His research covered the purification and crystallization of a. number of very important enzymes which take part in forming and utilizing energy-rich compounds within the body.

eventgrp.event: B.S. Cooper Union, New York City (1910 entered School of Chemistry)
Extension Teaching Columbia University, New York City
School of Mines, Engineering and Chemistry, Columbia Univ.
Faculty of Pure Science, Columbia University
Ph. D. Columbia University, New York City (Biological Chemistry)
Technical Assistant, Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research Worked with Jacques Loeb in experimental biology. From 1926 with John Northrop at Princeton laboratories
Civilian with Office of Scientific Research and Development
Carl Neuberg Medal (American Society of European Chemists & Pharmacists)
Honorary Degree, RU, New York City
Died April 20 in Philadelphia, Pa. Interred Wellwood Cemetery on Long Island, N.Y.

bioghist.p: Member of: National Academy of Sciences, American Association for the Advancement of Science, Society for Experimental Biology, Society of General Physiologists, American Society of Biological Chemists

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged in chronological order within subject.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Materials requiring specialized equipment for access (film, audio, video, slides) may be closed to research dependent on availability of the applicable equipment
Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be closed to researchers at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services/Head of Reference.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Dates received or inventoried: 1970, 1974, 1978, 1984. All received or inventoried in 1970, 1974, or 1978 unless otherwise noted.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
